title: Anchor-Based Approaches
text: Let’s start basic clinical significance distribution analysis using antidepressants dataset. interested Mind Mood Depression Inventory (mom_di) measurements want set Minimally Important Difference (MID) improvement value 7. ’s breakdown code: patient, measurement, mom_di variables representing patient identifiers, assessment time points, Mind Mood Depression Intentory (MoM-DI) scores, respectively. mid_improvement sets improvement 7.
code: anchor_results <- antidepressants |>    cs_anchor(     id = patient,     time = measurement,     outcome = mom_di,     mid_improvement = 7   ) #> ℹ Your "Before" was set as pre measurement and and your "After" as post. #> • If that is not correct, please specify the pre measurement with the argument #>   "pre".

title: Combined Approach
text: Let’s start basic statistical clinical significance analysis using antidepressants dataset. interested Mind Mood Depression Inventory (mom_di) measurements. statistical approach, functional population must defined. Suppose, collected data non-clinical sample determined mean 7 points standard deviation also 7 points. Furthermore, MID 8 points regarded minimally important.
code: combined_results <- antidepressants |>    cs_combined(     id = patient,     time = measurement,     outcome = mom_di,     m_functional = 7,     sd_functional = 7,     cutoff_type = "c",     mid_improvement = 8   ) #> ℹ Your "Before" was set as pre measurement and and your "After" as post. #> • If that is not correct, please specify the pre measurement with the argument #>   "pre".

title: Combined Approach
text: Sometimes, example , may encounter warnings using function. can turn warning explicitly specifying pre-measurement time point using pre parameter. can helpful data lacks clear pre-post measurement labels. ’s breakdown code: patient, measurement, mom_di represent patient identifier, assessment time points, HAM-D scores, respectively. pre post specify time points pre post-assessment. m_functional sd_functional define functional population’s mean standard deviation. information used calculate population cutoff. "c" specifies population cutoff choice. mid_improvement sets improvement 8.
code: # Turning off the warning by specifying pre-measurement time combined_results <- antidepressants |>    cs_combined(     id = patient,     time = measurement,     outcome = mom_di,     pre = "Before",     m_functional = 7,     sd_functional = 7,     cutoff_type = "c",     mid_improvement = 8   )

title: Percentage-Change Approach to Clinical Significance in R
text: Let’s start basic clinical significance distribution analysis using antidepressants dataset. interested Mind Mood Depression Inventory (mom_di) measurements want set percentage cutoff improvement value 0.3.
code: pct_results <- antidepressants |>    cs_percentage(     id = patient,     time = measurement,     outcome = mom_di,     pct_improvement = 0.3   ) #> ℹ Your "Before" was set as pre measurement and and your "After" as post. #> • If that is not correct, please specify the pre measurement with the argument #>   "pre".

title: Percentage-Change Approach to Clinical Significance in R
text: Sometimes, example , may encounter warnings using function. can turn warning explicitly specifying pre-measurement time point using pre parameter. can helpful data lacks clear pre-post measurement labels. ’s breakdown code: patient, measurement, mom_di represent patient identifier, assessment time points, HAM-D scores, respectively. pre post specify time points pre post-assessment. pct_improvement sets percentage change threshold improvement 30%.
code: # Turning off the warning by specifying pre-measurement time pct_results <- antidepressants |>   cs_percentage(     id = patient,     time = measurement,     outcome = mom_di,     pre = "Before",     pct_improvement = 0.5   )

title: Statistical Approach
text: Let’s start basic statistical clinical significance analysis using antidepressants dataset. interested Mind Mood Depression Inventory (mom_di) measurements. statistical approach, functional population must defined. Suppose, collected data non-clinical sample determined mean 7 points standard deviation also 7 points.
code: stat_results <- antidepressants |>    cs_statistical(     id = patient,     time = measurement,     outcome = mom_di,     m_functional = 7,     sd_functional = 7,     cutoff_type = "c"   ) #> ℹ Your "Before" was set as pre measurement and and your "After" as post. #> • If that is not correct, please specify the pre measurement with the argument #>   "pre".

title: Statistical Approach
text: Sometimes, example , may encounter warnings using function. can turn warning explicitly specifying pre-measurement time point using pre parameter. can helpful data lacks clear pre-post measurement labels. ’s breakdown code: patient, measurement, mom_di represent patient identifier, assessment time points, HAM-D scores, respectively. pre post specify time points pre post-assessment. m_functional sd_functional define functional population’s mean standard deviation. information used calculate population cutoff. "c" specifies population cutoff choice.
code: # Turning off the warning by specifying pre-measurement time stat_results <- antidepressants |>   cs_statistical(     id = patient,     time = measurement,     outcome = mom_di,     pre = "Before",     m_functional = 7,     sd_functional = 7,     cutoff_type = "c"   )

title: An R-Package for Clinical Significance Analyses
text: Claus et al. (2020) implemented novel intervention enhance effectiveness antidepressants boosting inherent placebo effect medication. randomized patients treatment usual (TAU) placebo amplification (PA) group measured severity depressive symptoms time. anchor-based approach, clinical significant change believed occured given change greater equal minimally important difference used instrument. Given tidy dataset study minimally important difference Beck Depression Inventory (second edition, BDI-II) 7 points, study data Claus et al. (2020) may analyzed follows: can receive detailed summary analysis plot cs_results
code: library(clinicalsignificance)  cs_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_anchor(     id = id,     time = time,     outcome = bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     mid_improvement = 7   )  cs_results #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:          Anchor-based #> MID Improvement:   7 #> MID Deterioration: 7 #> Better is:         Lower #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |  62.50% #> Unchanged    | 11 |  27.50% #> Deteriorated |  4 |  10.00% summary(cs_results) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:          Anchor-based #> MID Improvement:   7 #> MID Deterioration: 7 #> N (original):      43 #> N (used):          40 #> Percent (used):    93.02% #> Better is:         Lower #> Outcome:           bdi #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |  62.50% #> Unchanged    | 11 |  27.50% #> Deteriorated |  4 |  10.00% plot(cs_results)

code: cs_anchor(   data,   id,   time,   outcome,   group,   pre = NULL,   post = NULL,   mid_improvement = NULL,   mid_deterioration = NULL,   better_is = c("lower", "higher"),   target = c("individual", "group"),   effect = c("within", "between"),   bayesian = TRUE,   prior_scale = "medium",   reference_group = NULL,   ci_level = 0.95 )

title: Anchor-Based Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_anchor
text: data tidy data frame id Participant ID time Time variable outcome Outcome variable group Grouping variable (optional) pre Pre measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) post Post measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) mid_improvement Numeric, change indicates clinically significant improvement mid_deterioration Numeric, change indicates clinically significant deterioration (optional). mid_deterioration provided, assumed equal mid_improvement better_is direction means better outcome used instrument? Available "lower" (lower outcome scores desirable, default) "higher" (higher outcome scores desirable) target String, whether individual group analysis calculated. Available "individual" (default) every individual participant evaluated "group" group wise effect evaluated effect String, target = "group", specify effect calculated. Available "within" (default), yields mean pre-post intervention difference associated confidence intervals "", estimates group wise mean difference confidence intervals two groups specified group argument specified measurement supplied post- argument reference group may supplied reference_group bayesian Logical, relevant target = "group". Indicates Bayesian estimate (.e., median) group differences credible interval calculated (set TRUE, default) frequentist mean difference confidence interval (set FALSE) prior_scale String numeric, can adjusted change Bayesian prior distribution. See documentation rscale BayesFactor::ttestBF() details. reference_group Specify reference group subsequent groups compared target = "group" effect = "within" (optional). Otherwise, first distinct group chosen based alphabetical, numerical factor ordering. ci_level Numeric, define credible confidence interval level. default 0.95 95%-CI.

title: Anchor-Based Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_anchor
text: individual-level analyses, analysis straight forward. MID can specified improvement well deterioration (must necessarily identical) function basically counts many patients fall within MID range , improvement deterioration, many patients exceed limits range either direction. patient may categorized : Improved, patient demonstrated change equal greater MID improvement Unchanged, patient demonstrated change less MIDs Deteriorated, patient demonstrated change equal greater MID deterioration group-level analyses, whole sample either treated single group split grouping presented data. within group analyses, function calculates median change pre post intervention associated credible interval (CI). Based median change limits CI, group change can categorized 5 distinctive categories: Statistically significant, CI contains 0 Statistically significant clinically relevant, CI contain 0, median CI limits beneath MID threshold significantly less threshold, MID threshold falls within CI median still threshold Probably clinically significant effect, median crossed MID threshold threshold still inside CI Large clinically significant effect, median crossed MID threshold CI contain threshold group comparison desired, reference group can defined reference_group argument subsequent groups compared. usually inactive comparator placebo wait-list control group. difference pairwise compared groups categorized just within group difference , categories apply. approach can changed classical frequentist framework point estimate represents mean difference CI confidence interval. extensive overview differences Bayesian frequentist CI, refer Hespanhol et al. (2019).

what: Combined Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_combined
title: Combined Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_combined
text: cs_combined() can used determine clinical significance intervention studies employing combination distribution-based statistical approach. , assumed functional (non-clinical population) patient (clinical population) scores form two distinct distributions continuum. cs_combined() calculates cutoff point two populations well reliable change index (RCI) based provided instrument reliability estimate counts, many patients showed reliable change (likely due measurement error) switched clinical functional population intervention. Several methods calculating cutoff RCI available.

title: Combined Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_combined
code: cs_combined(   data,   id,   time,   outcome,   group = NULL,   pre = NULL,   post = NULL,   mid_improvement = NULL,   mid_deterioration = NULL,   reliability = NULL,   reliability_post = NULL,   m_functional = NULL,   sd_functional = NULL,   better_is = c("lower", "higher"),   rci_method = c("JT", "GLN", "HLL", "EN", "NK", "HA", "HLM"),   cutoff_type = c("a", "b", "c"),   significance_level = 0.05 )

Available "lower" (lower outcome scores desirable, default) "higher" (higher outcome scores desirable) rci_method Clinical significance method. Available "JT" (Jacobson & Truax, 1991, default) "GLN" (Gulliksen, Lord, Novick; Hsu, 1989, Hsu, 1995) "HLL" (Hsu, Linn & Nord; Hsu, 1989) "EN" (Edwards & Nunnally; Speer, 1992) "NK" (Nunnally & Kotsch, 1983), requires reliability estimate post measurement. supplied, reliability reliability_post assumed equal "HA" (Hageman & Arrindell, 1999) "HLM" (Hierarchical Linear Modeling; Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002), requires least three measurements per patient cutoff_type Cutoff type. Available "", "b", "c". Defaults "" "c" usually recommended. "positive" outcomes, higher scores beneficial, mean clinical population plus 2 \(\cdot\) SD clinical population b mean functional population minus 2 \(\cdot\) SD clinical population. summary statistics clinical population estimated provided data pre measurement. c defined midpoint populations based respective mean SD. order calculate b c, descriptive statistics functional population must provided. provided data, region change calculated individual change may likely due inherent measurement used instrument. concept also known minimally detectable change (MDC).

title: Distribution-Based Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_distribution
text: cs_distribution() can used determine clinical significance intervention studies employing distribution-based approach. , reliable change index estimated provided data known reliability estimate indicates, observed individual change likely greater measurement error inherent used instrument. case, reliable change defined clinically significant. Several methods calculating RCI can chosen.

title: Distribution-Based Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_distribution
code: cs_distribution(   data,   id,   time,   outcome,   group = NULL,   pre = NULL,   post = NULL,   reliability = NULL,   reliability_post = NULL,   better_is = c("lower", "higher"),   rci_method = c("JT", "GLN", "HLL", "EN", "NK", "HA", "HLM"),   significance_level = 0.05 )

title: Distribution-Based Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_distribution
text: data tidy data frame id Participant ID time Time variable outcome Outcome variable group Grouping variable (optional) pre Pre measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) post Post measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) reliability instrument's reliability estimate. selected NK method, specified reliability instrument's pre measurement reliability. needed HLM method. reliability_post instrument's reliability post measurement (needed NK method) better_is direction means better outcome used instrument? Available "lower" (lower outcome scores desirable, default) "higher" (higher outcome scores desirable) rci_method Clinical significance method. Available "JT" (Jacobson & Truax, 1991, default) "GLN" (Gulliksen, Lord, Novick; Hsu, 1989, Hsu, 1995) "HLL" (Hsu, Linn & Nord; Hsu, 1989) "EN" (Edwards & Nunnally; Speer, 1992) "NK" (Nunnally & Kotsch, 1983), requires reliability estimate post measurement. supplied, reliability reliability_post assumed equal "HA" (Hageman & Arrindell, 1999) "HLM" (Hierarchical Linear Modeling; Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002), requires least three measurements per patient significance_level Significance level alpha, defaults 0.05. choose "HA" method, value corresponds maximum risk misclassification

Hierarchical Linear Modeling (rci_method = "HLM") method can incorporate data multiple measurements can thus used least three measurements per participant.

title: Distribution-Based Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_distribution
code: antidepressants |>   cs_distribution(patient, measurement, mom_di, reliability = 0.80) #> ℹ Your "Before" was set as pre measurement and and your "After" as post. #> • If that is not correct, please specify the pre measurement with the argument #>   "pre". #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:   Distribution-based #> RCI Method: JT #>  #> Category     |   N | Percent #> ---------------------------- #> Improved     | 274 |  49.37% #> Unchanged    | 237 |  42.70% #> Deteriorated |  44 |   7.93% #>    # Turn off the warning by providing the pre measurement time cs_results <- antidepressants |>   cs_distribution(     patient,     measurement,     mom_di,     pre = "Before",     reliability = 0.80   )  summary(cs_results) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:     Distribution-based #> RCI Method:   JT #> N (original): 555 #> N (used):     555 #> Percent used: 100.00% #> Outcome:      mom_di #> Reliability:  0.8 #>  #> Category     |   N | Percent #> ---------------------------- #> Improved     | 274 |  49.37% #> Unchanged    | 237 |  42.70% #> Deteriorated |  44 |   7.93% #>  plot(cs_results)    # If you use data with more than two measurements, you always have to define a # pre and post measurement cs_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_distribution(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     reliability = 0.80   )  cs_results #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:   Distribution-based #> RCI Method: JT #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 29 |  72.50% #> Unchanged    | 10 |  25.00% #> Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% #>  summary(cs_results) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:     Distribution-based #> RCI Method:   JT #> N (original): 43 #> N (used):     40 #> Percent used: 93.02% #> Outcome:      hamd #> Reliability:  0.8 #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 29 |  72.50% #> Unchanged    | 10 |  25.00% #> Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% #>  plot(cs_results)    # Set the rci_method argument to change the RCI method cs_results_ha <- claus_2020 |>   cs_distribution(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     reliability = 0.80,     rci_method = "HA"   )  cs_results_ha #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:   Distribution-based #> RCI Method: HA #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 32 |  80.00% #> Unchanged    |  7 |  17.50% #> Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% #>  summary(cs_results_ha) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:     Distribution-based #> RCI Method:   HA #> N (original): 43 #> N (used):     40 #> Percent used: 93.02% #> Outcome:      hamd #> Reliability:  0.8 #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 32 |  80.00% #> Unchanged    |  7 |  17.50% #> Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% #>  plot(cs_results_ha)    # Group the analysis by providing a grouping variable cs_results_grouped <- claus_2020 |>   cs_distribution(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     group = treatment,     reliability = 0.80   )  cs_results_grouped #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:   Distribution-based #> RCI Method: JT #>  #> Group |     Category |  N | Percent | Percent by Group #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> TAU   |     Improved |  9 |  22.50% |           47.37% #> TAU   |    Unchanged |  9 |  22.50% |           47.37% #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% |            5.26% #> PA    |     Improved | 20 |  50.00% |           95.24% #> PA    |    Unchanged |  1 |   2.50% |            4.76% #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% |            0.00% #>  summary(cs_results_grouped) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:     Distribution-based #> RCI Method:   JT #> N (original): 43 #> N (used):     40 #> Percent used: 93.02% #> Outcome:      hamd #> Reliability:  0.8 #>  #> Group |     Category |  N | Percent | Percent by Group #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> TAU   |     Improved |  9 |  22.50% |           47.37% #> TAU   |    Unchanged |  9 |  22.50% |           47.37% #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% |            5.26% #> PA    |     Improved | 20 |  50.00% |           95.24% #> PA    |    Unchanged |  1 |   2.50% |            4.76% #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% |            0.00% #>  plot(cs_results_grouped)    # Use more than two measurements cs_results_hlm <- claus_2020 |>   cs_distribution(     id,     time,     hamd,     rci_method = "HLM"   )  cs_results_hlm #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:   Distribution-based #> RCI Method: HLM #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 11 |  27.50% #> Unchanged    | 20 |  50.00% #> Deteriorated |  9 |  22.50% #>  summary(cs_results_hlm) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:     Distribution-based #> RCI Method:   HLM #> N (original): 43 #> N (used):     40 #> Percent used: 93.02% #> Outcome:      hamd #> Reliability:  ---- #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 11 |  27.50% #> Unchanged    | 20 |  50.00% #> Deteriorated |  9 |  22.50% #>  plot(cs_results_hlm)

title: Percentage-Change Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_percentage
text: data tidy data frame id Participant ID time Time variable outcome Outcome variable group Grouping variable (optional) pre Pre measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) post Post measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) pct_improvement Numeric, percent change indicates clinically significant improvement pct_deterioration Numeric, percent change indicates clinically significant deterioration (optional). set, pct_deterioration assumed equal pct_improvement better_is direction means better outcome used instrument? Available "lower" (lower outcome scores desirable, default) "higher" (higher outcome scores desirable)

title: Percentage-Change Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_percentage

title: Percentage-Change Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_percentage
text: individual's change may categorized one following three categories: Improved, change greater predefined percent change beneficial direction Unchanged, change within predefined percent change Deteriorated, change greater predefined percent change, disadvantageous direction

title: Percentage-Change Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_percentage
text: data set must tidy, corresponds long data frame general. must contain patient identifier must unique per patient. Also, column containing different measurements outcome must supplied. participant-measurement combination must unique, instance, data must contain two "" measurements patient. Additionally, measurement column contains two values, first value based alphabetical, numerical factor ordering used pre measurement. instance, column contains measurements identifiers "pre" "post" strings, "post" sorted "pre" thus used "pre" measurement. function throw warning generally may want explicitly define "pre" "post" measurement arguments pre post. case two measurement identifiers, define pre post manually since function know pre post intervention measurements . data grouped, can specify group referencing grouping variable (see examples ). analysis run every group compare group differences.

title: Percentage-Change Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_percentage
code: cs_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_percentage(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     pct_improvement = 0.3   )  cs_results #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:                 Percentage-based #> Percentage Improvement:   30.00% #> Percentage Deterioration: 30.00% #> Better is:                Lower #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |  62.50% #> Unchanged    | 15 |  37.50% #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% #>  summary(cs_results) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:                 Percentage-based #> Percentage Improvement:   30.00% #> Percentage Deterioration: 30.00% #> Better is:                Lower #> N (original):             43 #> N (used):                 40 #> Percent used:             93.02% #> Outcome:                  hamd #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |  62.50% #> Unchanged    | 15 |  37.50% #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% #>  plot(cs_results)    # You can set different thresholds for improvement and deterioration cs_results_2 <- claus_2020 |>   cs_percentage(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     pct_improvement = 0.3,     pct_deterioration = 0.2   )  cs_results_2 #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:                 Percentage-based #> Percentage Improvement:   30.00% #> Percentage Deterioration: 20.00% #> Better is:                Lower #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |  62.50% #> Unchanged    | 14 |  35.00% #> Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% #>  summary(cs_results_2) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:                 Percentage-based #> Percentage Improvement:   30.00% #> Percentage Deterioration: 20.00% #> Better is:                Lower #> N (original):             43 #> N (used):                 40 #> Percent used:             93.02% #> Outcome:                  hamd #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |  62.50% #> Unchanged    | 14 |  35.00% #> Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% #>  plot(cs_results_2)    # You can group the analysis by providing a group column from the data cs_results_grouped <- claus_2020 |>   cs_percentage(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     pct_improvement = 0.3,     group = treatment   )  cs_results_grouped #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:                 Percentage-based #> Percentage Improvement:   30.00% #> Percentage Deterioration: 30.00% #> Better is:                Lower #>  #> Group |     Category |  N | Percent | Percent by Group #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> TAU   |     Improved |  6 |  15.00% |           31.58% #> TAU   |    Unchanged | 13 |  32.50% |           68.42% #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% |            0.00% #> PA    |     Improved | 19 |  47.50% |           90.48% #> PA    |    Unchanged |  2 |   5.00% |            9.52% #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% |            0.00% #>  summary(cs_results_grouped) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:                 Percentage-based #> Percentage Improvement:   30.00% #> Percentage Deterioration: 30.00% #> Better is:                Lower #> N (original):             43 #> N (used):                 40 #> Percent used:             93.02% #> Outcome:                  hamd #>  #> Group |     Category |  N | Percent | Percent by Group #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> TAU   |     Improved |  6 |  15.00% |           31.58% #> TAU   |    Unchanged | 13 |  32.50% |           68.42% #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% |            0.00% #> PA    |     Improved | 19 |  47.50% |           90.48% #> PA    |    Unchanged |  2 |   5.00% |            9.52% #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% |            0.00% #>  plot(cs_results_grouped)    # The analyses can be performed for positive outcomes as well, i.e., outcomes # for which a higher value is beneficial cs_results_who <- claus_2020 |>   cs_percentage(     id,     time,     who,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     pct_improvement = 0.3,     better_is = "higher"   )  cs_results_who #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:                 Percentage-based #> Percentage Improvement:   30.00% #> Percentage Deterioration: 30.00% #> Better is:                Higher #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 28 |  70.00% #> Unchanged    |  9 |  22.50% #> Deteriorated |  3 |   7.50% #>  summary(cs_results_who) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:                 Percentage-based #> Percentage Improvement:   30.00% #> Percentage Deterioration: 30.00% #> Better is:                Higher #> N (original):             43 #> N (used):                 40 #> Percent used:             93.02% #> Outcome:                  who #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 28 |  70.00% #> Unchanged    |  9 |  22.50% #> Deteriorated |  3 |   7.50% #>  plot(cs_results_who)  plot(cs_results_who, show = category)

what: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: cs_statistical() can used determine clinical significance intervention studies employing statistical approach. , assumed functional (non-clinical population) patient (clinical population) scores form two distinct distributions continuum. cs_statistical() calculates cutoff point two populations counts, many patients changed clinical functional population intervention. Several methods calculating cutoff available.

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
code: cs_statistical(   data,   id,   time,   outcome,   group = NULL,   pre = NULL,   post = NULL,   m_functional = NULL,   sd_functional = NULL,   reliability = NULL,   better_is = c("lower", "higher"),   cutoff_method = c("JT", "HA"),   cutoff_type = c("a", "b", "c"),   significance_level = 0.05 )

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: data tidy data frame id Participant ID time Time variable outcome Outcome variable group Grouping variable (optional) pre Pre measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) post Post measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) m_functional Numeric, mean functional population. sd_functional Numeric, standard deviation functional population reliability instrument's reliability estimate. selected NK method, specified reliability instrument's pre measurement reliability. needed HLM method. better_is direction means better outcome used instrument? Available "lower" (lower outcome scores desirable, default) "higher" (higher outcome scores desirable) cutoff_method Cutoff method, Available "JT" (Jacobson & Truax, 1991, default) "HA" (Hageman & Arrindell, 1999) cutoff_type Cutoff type. Available "", "b", "c". Defaults "" "c" usually recommended. "b" "c", summary data functional population must given arguments m_functional sd_functional. significance_level Significance level alpha, defaults 0.05. choose "HA" method, value corresponds maximum risk misclassification

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: S3 object class cs_analysis cs_statistical

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: three available cutoff types, namely , b, c can used "draw line" separate functional clinical population continuum. cutoff defined mean clinical population minus two times standard deviation (SD) clinical population. b defined mean functional population plus also two times SD clinical population. true "negative" outcomes, lower instrument score desirable. "positive" outcomes, higher scores beneficial, mean clinical population plus 2 \(\cdot\) SD clinical population b mean functional population minus 2 \(\cdot\) SD clinical population. summary statistics clinical population estimated provided data pre measurement. c defined midpoint populations based respective mean SD. order calculate b c, descriptive statistics functional population must provided.

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: Individual patients can categorized one following groups: Improved, .e., one changed clinical functional population Unchanged, .e., one can seen member population pre post intervention Deteriorated, .e., one changed functional clinical population intervention

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: data set must tidy, corresponds long data frame general. must contain patient identifier must unique per patient. Also, column containing different measurements outcome must supplied. participant-measurement combination must unique, instance, data must contain two "" measurements patient. Additionally, measurement column contains two values, first value based alphabetical, numerical factor ordering used pre measurement. instance, column contains measurements identifiers "pre" "post" strings, "post" sorted "pre" thus used "pre" measurement. function throw warning generally may want explicitly define "pre" "post" measurement arguments pre post. case two measurement identifiers, define pre post manually since function know pre post intervention measurements . data grouped, can specify group referencing grouping variable (see examples ). analysis run every group compare group differences.

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: Jacobson, N. S., & Truax, P. (1991). Clinical significance: statistical approach defining meaningful change psychotherapy research. Journal Consulting Clinical Psychology, 59(1), 12–19. https://doi.org/10.1037//0022-006X.59.1.12 Hageman, W. J., & Arrindell, W. . (1999). Establishing clinically significant change: increment precision distinction individual group level analysis. Behaviour Research Therapy, 37(12), 1169–1193. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0005-7967(99)00032-7

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
code: # By default, cutoff type "a" is used cs_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_statistical(id, time, hamd, pre = 1, post = 4)  cs_results #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach: Statistical #> Method:   JT #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 26 |  65.00% #> Unchanged    | 13 |  32.50% #> Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% #>  summary(cs_results) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:     Statistical #> Method:       JT #> N (original): 43 #> N (used):     40 #> Percent used: 93.02% #> Cutoff type:  a #> Cutoff:       18.17 #>  #> -- Cutoff Descriptives #>  #> M Clinical | SD Clinical | M Functional | SD Functional #> ------------------------------------------------------- #> 24.85      |        3.34 |          --- |           --- #>  #>  #> -- Results #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 26 |  65.00% #> Unchanged    | 13 |  32.50% #> Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% #>  plot(cs_results)    # You can choose a different cutoff type but need to provide additional # population summary statistics for the functional population cs_results_c <- claus_2020 |>   cs_statistical(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 8,     sd_functional = 8,     cutoff_type = "c"   )  cs_results_c #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach: Statistical #> Method:   JT #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 26 |  65.00% #> Unchanged    | 13 |  32.50% #> Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% #>  summary(cs_results_c) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:     Statistical #> Method:       JT #> N (original): 43 #> N (used):     40 #> Percent used: 93.02% #> Cutoff type:  c #> Cutoff:       19.89 #>  #> -- Cutoff Descriptives #>  #> M Clinical | SD Clinical | M Functional | SD Functional #> ------------------------------------------------------- #> 24.85      |        3.34 |            8 |             8 #>  #>  #> -- Results #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 26 |  65.00% #> Unchanged    | 13 |  32.50% #> Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% #>  plot(cs_results_c)    # You can use a different method to calculate the cutoff cs_results_ha <- claus_2020 |>   cs_statistical(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 8,     sd_functional = 8,     reliability = 0.80,     cutoff_type = "c",     cutoff_method = "HA"   )  cs_results_ha #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach: Statistical #> Method:   HA #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 23 |  57.50% #> Unchanged    | 17 |  42.50% #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% #>  summary(cs_results_ha) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:     Statistical #> Method:       HA #> N (original): 43 #> N (used):     40 #> Percent used: 93.02% #> Cutoff type:  c_true #> Cutoff:       20.21 #>  #> -- Cutoff Descriptives #>  #> M Clinical | SD Clinical | M Functional | SD Functional #> ------------------------------------------------------- #> 24.85      |        3.34 |            8 |             8 #>  #>  #> -- Results #>  #> Category     |  N | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 23 |  57.50% #> Unchanged    | 17 |  42.50% #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% #>  plot(cs_results_ha)    # And you can group the analysis by providing a grouping variable from the data cs_results_grouped <- claus_2020 |>   cs_statistical(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 8,     sd_functional = 8,     cutoff_type = "c",     group = treatment   )  cs_results_grouped #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach: Statistical #> Method:   JT #>  #> Group |     Category |  N | Percent | Percent by Group #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> TAU   |     Improved |  7 |  17.50% |           36.84% #> TAU   |    Unchanged | 11 |  27.50% |           57.89% #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% |            5.26% #> PA    |     Improved | 19 |  47.50% |           90.48% #> PA    |    Unchanged |  2 |   5.00% |            9.52% #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% |            0.00% #>  summary(cs_results_grouped) #>  #> ---- Clinical Significance Results ---- #>  #> Approach:     Statistical #> Method:       JT #> N (original): 43 #> N (used):     40 #> Percent used: 93.02% #> Cutoff type:  c #> Cutoff:       19.89 #>  #> -- Cutoff Descriptives #>  #> M Clinical | SD Clinical | M Functional | SD Functional #> ------------------------------------------------------- #> 24.85      |        3.34 |            8 |             8 #>  #>  #> -- Results #>  #> Group |     Category |  N | Percent | Percent by Group #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> TAU   |     Improved |  7 |  17.50% |           36.84% #> TAU   |    Unchanged | 11 |  27.50% |           57.89% #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  1 |   2.50% |            5.26% #> PA    |     Improved | 19 |  47.50% |           90.48% #> PA    |    Unchanged |  2 |   5.00% |            9.52% #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |   0.00% |            0.00% #>  plot(cs_results_grouped)

title: Get A Summary Table From A cs_analysis Object — cs_get_summary
code: anchor_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_anchor(     id,     time,     bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     mid_improvement = 8   )  cs_get_summary(anchor_results) #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   category         n percent #>   <fct>        <int>   <dbl> #> 1 Improved        20   0.5   #> 2 Unchanged       17   0.425 #> 3 Deteriorated     3   0.075   # Get summary table for a group level analysis anchor_results_grouped <- claus_2020 |>   cs_anchor(     id,     time,     bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     mid_improvement = 8,     target = "group"   )  cs_get_summary(anchor_results_grouped) #> # A tibble: 1 × 6 #>   difference lower upper    ci     n category                               #>        <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> <chr>                                  #> 1      -9.40 -12.8 -5.85  0.95    40 Probably clinically significant effect   # Get group-wise summary table for the Hageman & Arrindell method combined_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_combined(     id,     time,     bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 8,     sd_functional = 8,     reliability = 0.80,     rci_method = "HA"   )  cs_get_summary(combined_results) #> $individual_level_summary #> #
